questions.question: When will I be eligible to get the vaccine?
questions.answer:
To learn when it will be your turn to get a COVID vaccine, contact your [state health department](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/php/open-america/hd-search/index.html). 

States are following the distribution advice of the [Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/acip/index.html) (ACIP), a group of medical and public health experts who develop recommendations on the use of vaccines. The ACIP determined that health care workers and staff and residents of nursing homes and assisted living facilities should be vaccinated first. But each state has adopted its own priorities for who to include in subsequent vaccination groups. Learn more through this analysis by the [Kaiser Family Foundation](https://www.kff.org/policy-watch/the-covid-19-vaccine-priority-line-continues-to-change-as-states-make-further-updates/).

As the vaccine supply increases, more groups will be added, with the goal of there being enough vaccines for everyone in the U.S. who wants one to be able to get one easily, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html).

questions.question: Who pays for vaccination?
questions.answer: Under the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, a COVID vaccine must be free of charge to anyone who wants it. The federal government has purchased millions of vaccine shots and distributed them to providers. While providers may charge a fee for administering the vaccine, both private insurance and public programs must cover 100 percent of the fee, according to the [Kaiser Family Foundation](https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-covid-19/issue-brief/vaccine-coverage-pricing-and-reimbursement-in-the-u-s/). Uninsured patients also face no charges, as providers are reimbursed for administrative costs by the [Provider Relief Fund](https://www.hrsa.gov/coronavirus), which was established under the CARES Act.

questions.question: Are COVID vaccines safe?
questions.answer:
Approved COVID vaccines were developed in record time, but this does not mean that any safety protocols were bypassed. All vaccines have gone through rigorous testing to ensure their safety. Each vaccine must undergo clinical trials, with study participants followed for two months after completing a vaccination series to prove that the vaccine is safe and effective, according to the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinichealthsystem.org/hometown-health/featured-topic/covid-19-vaccine-myths-debunked). After the Food and Drug Administration determines that a vaccine is safe, the Advisory Committee on Immunization carefully reviews all available data before making its recommendation to the CDC.

Even after a vaccine is in use, the CDC continues to monitor its safety. Health care providers, for instance, are required to report adverse vaccine reactions to a [national warning system](https://vaers.hhs.gov/about.html). Fortunately, of the first 1.9 million people to receive shots of Pfizer-BioNTech’s COVID vaccine, only 0.2% [experienced an adverse event](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/wr/mm7002e1.htm), such as fatique or headache, and very few reactions were serious.

Learn more about [how federal partners are ensuring the safety of COVID vaccines in the United States.](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety.html)

questions.question: What are the side effects of the vaccine?
questions.answer:
Not everyone experiences side effects, but if you do, it is generally a sign that your body is building protection. While side effects may get in the way of your daily activities, they typically go away in a few days. According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect/after.html), side effects may include: 

* **Pain and swelling on your arm** **where you received the shot**. This can be alleviated by applying a clean, cool, wet washcloth over the area, or by using or exercising your arm. 
* **Fever, chills, tiredness, and headache**. To reduce discomfort from fever, drink plenty of fluids and dress lightly. You may also want to talk to your doctor about taking an over-the-counter medicine, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen. 

You may want to contact your doctor or healthcare provider if: 

* The area around your shot becomes more red and tender after 24 hours.
* Your side effects last longer than a few days or you feel concerned.

questions.question: What are the ingredients of the vaccines?
questions.answer:
According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html), the two COVID vaccines currently available in the United States do not contain eggs, preservatives, or latex. For a full list of ingredients, please see each vaccine’s fact sheet:

* [Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine](https://www.fda.gov/media/144414/download)
* [Moderna COVID-19 vaccine](https://www.fda.gov/media/144638/download)

questions.question: What percentage of people need to be vaccinated to achieve herd immunity?
questions.answer: [Herd immunity](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#herd-immunity) is when a large enough portion of a community is immune to a virus so that the virus can no longer spread easily from person to person. At this time, experts do not know what percentage of people need to be vaccinated to achieve herd immunity to COVID. The [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html) and other experts continue to study the topic and will provide more information as it is available.

questions.question: If I’ve already had and recovered from COVID, should I still get vaccinated?
questions.answer:
Yes, even those who have had COVID should get vaccinated from the disease, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html). While getting COVID may provide you with some natural immunity, it’s not clear how long this protection may last, says the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/in-depth/coronavirus-vaccine/art-20484859#:~:text=Getting%20COVID%2D19%20might,COVID%2D19%20vaccine.). Some [studies](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(20)30764-7/fulltext) have found that reinfection is possible, but a vaccine could boost your immune response.

 If you recently had COVID or were treated for COVID with monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma, the CDC recommends that you wait 90 days before getting a vaccine.

questions.question: If I get a COVID vaccine, do I still need to wear a mask and practice social distancing?
questions.answer:
Yes. A vaccine will help protect you from getting sick if you are exposed to COVID, but it may not prevent you from carrying and transmitting the virus to others, according to experts at [Duke University Health System](https://www.dukehealth.org/covid-19-update/covid-19-vaccine-FAQ). Until enough people have been vaccinated, it is important to continue to wear masks, practice social distancing and take other precautions. 

In time, we’ll know more about the protection that COVID vaccines provide. Such factors as the number of people getting vaccinated and how the virus is spreading in communities may affect the advice, says the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html).

questions.question: Does immunity protection last longer if you get a vaccine or if you have had COVID?
questions.answer:
Studies about immunity after COVID infection have had conflicting findings. Some [studies](https://www.technologyreview.com/2020/07/13/1005103/immunity-to-covid-19-could-disappear-in-months-a-new-study-suggests/) have found that immunity goes away quickly, but more recent [studies](https://www.technologyreview.com/2021/01/06/1015822/covid-19-immunity-likely-lasts-for-years/) have found that your body has robust immunity for many months. 

The upshot: With any new disease, we don’t know how long infection-acquired immunity might last—or how much it might vary from person to person, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html). This is also true for COVID vaccines. Until we have more data on how well the vaccines work in real-world conditions, we will not know how long immunity will last.

questions.question: How do you get your vaccine eligibility information?
questions.answer: Our team of staff and volunteers review official government sites of states, metros and counties several times a week.

questions.question: Why do you have vaccine eligibility information for some locations and not others?
questions.answer: Identifying vaccine eligibility information takes time, since the information is not standardized and cannot be processed automatically by a computer. It thus needs to be collected manually. What’s more, eligibility varies not only from state to state, but also sometimes by county, and even by city. Finally, vaccine eligibility information may change as states, counties, or cities adjust their roll-out plans, and making sure this information is up to date is a manual process of regularly checking government websites. For all those reasons, we currently have a limited number of locations that we are able to support with vaccine eligibility alerts.

questions.question: Which locations do you have vaccine eligibility information for?
questions.answer: We currently only have vaccine eligibility information for all 50 states.

questions.question: How is the coronavirus transmitted?
questions.answer: Evidence suggests that COVID spreads mainly from person to person, primarily through respiratory droplets that are released when a person sneezes, coughs, or talks. These droplets are propelled through the air and can land in the noses and mouths of people, especially those in close proximity (six feet or less), according to the [Centers for Disease Control](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html) (CDC) and [World Health Organization](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/question-and-answers-hub/q-a-detail/q-a-how-is-covid-19-transmitted?gclid=Cj0KCQjwqrb7BRDlARIsACwGad6u8LD7qnGFt5oFPYI4ngBzLUHYz2-9DZ_b4fruyio4ekVFoQR7l7YaAsm3EALw_wcB) (WHO). [Research](https://www.pnas.org/content/117/26/14857) supported by the CDC also suggests that COVID may spread through aerosol, or airborne, [transmission](/glossary#transmission). This is similar to transmission by droplets except that the amounts of fluid are much smaller and can linger in the air for a much longer time and [infect](/glossary#infection) people further than six feet away.

questions.question: How long does the coronavirus live on surfaces?
questions.answer: The [virus](/glossary#virus) can live from several hours to several days on surfaces, depending on the type of material (cardboard, plastic, etc.). Even so, the CDC says that COVID is not transmitted easily through surfaces and spreads mainly from person-to-person. If you are concerned about surface contamination, you can find details on appropriate cleaning and sanitizing protocols from the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/pdf/Reopening_America_Guidance.pdf#:~:text=Coronaviruses%20on%20surfaces%20and%20objects,and%20dirt%20from%20surfaces.).

questions.question: Who is most at risk of getting COVID?
questions.answer: Anyone who has been [exposed](/glossary#exposed) to COVID is at risk of contracting the disease, and people of all ages have experienced hospitalization and death. Some people, however, are at greater risk. Elderly individuals, particularly those 85 or older, and people with certain underlying medical conditions are at [higher risk](/glossary#comorbidity) of serious illness, according to the CDC. (Read more about people at increased risk of contracting COVID at the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/index.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fneed-extra-precautions%2Fpeople-at-increased-risk.html).)

questions.question: Which racial and ethnic minorities are at higher risk of contracting COVID and becoming seriously ill?
questions.answer:
Data from the CDC shows that race and ethnicity, similar to age, are risk factors for COVID. The rates of COVID cases, hospitalizations and deaths among Blacks, Hispanic and Latino persons, and American Indians and Native Alaskans are much higher than for white people, according to the CDC’s calculation of [COVID-19 Hospitalization and Death by Race/Ethnicity](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/investigations-discovery/hospitalization-death-by-race-ethnicity.html) (updated November 30, 2020). The [APM Research Lab](https://www.apmresearchlab.org/covid/deaths-by-race) finds that death rates are more than three times higher for Black, Latino, and Indigenous people than for white people (updated November 12, 2020).

A number of social factors contribute to COVID risk for racial and ethnic minorities. For example, many minorities have higher rates of poverty and less access to health care. This puts them at greater risk of underlying medical conditions that result in more severe COVID cases. Racial and ethnic minorities are also more likely to be essential workers, live in crowded multi-generational housing, and have less financial resources to take off work when sick or provide for necessities while sheltering in place. Discrimination, including racism, contributes to these long-term social deficits and more immediately to inadequate health care access, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/health-equity/race-ethnicity.html).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of COVID?
questions.answer: Symptoms of COVID vary widely between different people. The most common symptoms include fatigue, cough and fever. Loss of smell or taste is also a frequent, early symptom. Other symptoms that people with COVID may experience include shortness of breath, muscle or body ache, sore throat, chills, congestion, headache, stomach pain (including nausea and diarrhea), pink eye (conjunctivitis) and chest pain. COVID symptoms generally appear two to 14 days after exposure. For more information on symptoms and when to seek medical help, go to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html).

questions.question: How common is it to have COVID but not have any symptoms?
questions.answer: Many individuals infected with COVID are [asymptomatic](/glossary#asymptomatic) (that is, they do not have symptoms of the virus). When people do not know that they are ill, they do not take precautions. In much the same way, people who are “[presymptomatic](/glossary#presymptomatic-spread)” – that is, they will eventually develop symptoms ‒ may unknowingly spread the disease to others before they realize that they are ill. The [CDC estimates](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/planning-scenarios.html) that as many as 40 percent of COVID cases are asymptomatic.

questions.question: Are children at risk of becoming sick with COVID?
questions.answer: Children can become infected and sick with COVID. According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html#Children), fewer children get sick than adults and most display mild symptoms or are [asymptomatic](\[/glossary#asymptomatic]). However, children with underlying medical conditions or infants (less than 1 year old) may be at increased risk for severe illness. There have also been cases of a rare disease called [multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C)](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/children/mis-c.html), which has been linked to COVID.

questions.question: How long are you contagious with COVID?
questions.answer: According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/end-home-isolation.html), a person with COVID is most likely no longer contagious when (1) at least 10 days have passed since symptom onset; (2) at least 24 hours have passed fever-free without the use of fever-reducing medications; and (3) other symptoms have improved. If you never develop symptoms, you can still be contagious for 10 days after your first positive test. However, [experts](https://www.health.harvard.edu/diseases-and-conditions/if-youve-been-exposed-to-the-coronavirus#:~:text=Most%20people%20with%20coronavirus%20who,there%20are%20documented%20exceptions.) recommend quarantining for a full 14 days in case symptoms develop. You can ensure that you are no longer contagious with COVID after 10 days by receiving two [PCR](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#pcr-test) or [antigen](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#antigen-test) tests 24 hours apart that are both negative for the virus.

questions.question: Can you get COVID twice?
questions.answer: While [antibodies](/glossary#antibodies) may offer some protection against the virus and documented cases of reinfection are rare, there is no evidence to suggest that people are immune to COVID after their first infection. The current understanding of reinfection is limited due to the novelty of the virus, but ongoing studies will provide more insight into how frequently reinfection occurs and how long immunity from COVID may last after your first infection. Even if you’ve already had COVID or have antibodies, the [CDC recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/reinfection.html#:~:text=Cases%20of%20reinfection%20with%20COVID,some%20reinfections%20are%20expected.) taking the same precautions against the virus, including [mask wearing](/glossary#face-mask) and [social distancing](/glossary#social-distancing).

questions.question: What are the long-term effects of COVID?
questions.answer: While some people recover quickly from COVID, others suffer debilitating, long-term symptoms, according to the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/in-depth/coronavirus-long-term-effects/art-20490351). In Italy, which was one of the first countries to be hit hard by the disease, many survivors are still experiencing health problems after having COVID. In one [study](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2768351), more than 87 percent of individuals experienced one or more symptoms (most commonly fatigue and difficulty breathing) after recovery from COVID. Meanwhile, a German [study](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamacardiology/fullarticle/2768916) found that 78 of 100 recovered COVID patients continued to experience heart abnormalities months after [infection](/glossary#infection).

questions.question: What is counted as a COVID death?
questions.answer:
The [WHO](https://www.who.int/classifications/icd/Guidelines_Cause_of_Death_COVID-19.pdf?ua=1) states that a COVID death can be “a death resulting from a clinically compatible illness, in a probable or confirmed COVID-19 case, unless there is a clear alternative cause of death that cannot be related to COVID disease (e.g. trauma). There should be no period of complete recovery from COVID-19 between illness and death.” (The CDC’s  offers further [guidance](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/covid19/coding-and-reporting.htm) on reporting and coding deaths due to COVID.)

Tracking the number of COVID deaths is difficult, and some suggest that the number is underreported. One issue is that individuals infected with the [virus](/glossary#virus) may be sick for many days, or even weeks, before death, so the increase in deaths resulting from a [wave](/glossary#wave) of [infections](/glossary#infection) may lag significantly in time. In some cases people may die indirectly from COVID, because hospitals were overcrowded with COVID patients and care was late or unavailable. To track the number of COVID deaths, researchers rely on something called “excess mortality” — the number of deaths from all causes during a crisis that are above the historical average during non-crisis times. For information on excess mortality, see the CDC’s report, [Excess Deaths Associated with COVID-19](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/vsrr/covid19/excess_deaths.htm).

questions.question: Why is testing important?
questions.answer: Diagnostic testing allows health officials to identify and isolate infected individuals and begin [contact tracing](/glossary#contact-tracing) to [quarantine](/glossary#quarantine) people who were exposed. It also allows public health officials to collect the data and information necessary to know when it is safe to resume ordinary activities or when [non-pharmaceutical interventions](/glossary#npi) like [masks](/glossary#face-mask) are critical. Leaders of the [American Heart Association](https://healthmetrics.heart.org/covid-19-science-why-testing-is-so-important/), the [American Medical Association](https://www.ama-assn.org/delivering-care/public-health/why-cdc-was-right-revise-coronavirus-testing-guidelines) and the [National Institute on Aging](https://www.nia.nih.gov/news/why-covid-19-testing-key-getting-back-normal), among other organizations, have all urged for an expansion of testing.

questions.question: Why is a low positive test rate a good sign?
questions.answer: Many people infected with COVID are [pre-symptomatic](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#presymptomatic-spread) or [asymptomatic](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#asymptomatic), making it difficult to know how widespread the disease is in a community. If there is ample testing being done, including of individuals who have no reason to believe that they have the [virus](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#virus), then many negative test results will be received, leading to a low [test positivity rate](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#test-positivity). This is an indication that adequate testing is being done in an area and that there are not a lot of undetected cases in the community.

questions.question: When tests are conducted, where do the results get counted?
questions.answer: State reporting practices differ. In most states, the test results are reported where individuals are tested, not where they live. Florida, however, distinguishes between residents and non-residents in the statistics it publishes.

questions.question: What is R-naught (R0) and how is it different from R(t)?
questions.answer: [R-naught](covidactnow.org/glossary#r-0) (R₀), represents the natural ability of a virus to spread in an unprotected population where no special precautions are being taken. [R(t)](/glossary#rt), in contrast, takes into account public health measures or the development of a [vaccine](/glossary#vaccine). This makes R(t) —the actual or “effective” of the virus under current conditions —  a more accurate reflection of the number of people that a single infected person is expected to infect in a specific area at a specific time. It is also more relevant than R₀ in directing public policy and informing private behavior. The value of R(t) can change over time, depending on such factors as how many people are staying home or wearing masks. At Covid Act Now, we look at R(t), or [infection rate](https://covidactnow.org/covid-risk-levels-metrics#infection-rate), because it represents more closely what is happening right now and is calculated based on actual death and hospitalization data.

questions.question: Is it safe to reopen schools?
questions.answer: There are many ways that schools can reduce risk. For instance, schools may adopt plans to limit [infections](/glossary#infection), such as establishing effective protocols for testing, tracking and tracing, and providing [masks](/glossary#face-mask) and other [protective equipment](/glossary#ppe). Still, some schools may face limitations. They may have a greater density of students and employees in buildings, poorer ventilation and less opportunity for outdoor learning. Covid Act Now provides decision makers with [data](/glossary#data) to assess risk and consider the ability of the school and school district to keep students and teachers safe.

questions.question: How do I travel safely?
questions.answer: For the time being, it is safest not to travel. In particular, travel by plane, which may require you to sit close to others for hours, and by cruise ship are particularly risky, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/faqs.html). If you must travel, look at the data on [our site](https://covidactnow.org/?s=768133) to compare the state and county risk levels where you will be. If you plan to fly, take time to research and assess the measures different airlines are taking to reduce risky behaviors and comply with local laws to contain the spread of COVID. The CDC also strongly recommends wearing a face mask and offers [guidance]([what-masks-most-effective]) on choosing the best type.

questions.question: How soon after a possible exposure to COVID should I get tested?
questions.answer: It’s important to get tested for COVID after any potential [exposure](/glossary#exposed) to the [virus](/glossary#virus), whether that’s through contact with a [confirmed case](/glossary#confirmed-case) or traveling in close company with strangers. Since COVID has a long [incubation period](/glossary#incubation-period), it may take a few days before [PCR tests](/glossary#pcr-test) detect a sufficient enough amount of the virus to report a positive result, leading to high rates of [false-negatives](/glossary#false-negative) during the first few days after exposure. While it’s always recommended to [quarantine](/glossary#quarantine) for 14 days, [experts recommend](https://medical.mit.edu/covid-19-updates/2020/07/when-should-i-be-tested) being tested five to seven days after a probable exposure for the most accurate test results.

Rapid tests, also known as [antigen tests]([/glossary#antigen-tests]), and [PCR tests]([/glossary#PCR-test]) are the two types of diagnostic tests for COVID. Both tests are performed by collecting nasal or throat swabs, but antigen tests report results in minutes while PCR tests can take up to a week to return results depending on lab capacity. While rapid tests are more convenient and often cheaper, they report significantly higher rates of [false negatives](\[/glossary#false-negative]) of [up to 50 percent](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/which-test-is-best-for-covid-19-2020081020734). PCR tests, on the other hand, report between 2 percent to 37 percent false negatives. PCR tests are most accurate for detecting active infections, while rapid tests are [best used](https://twitter.com/covidactnow/status/1321254254997204992?s=21) to confirm COVID symptoms.
questions.question: Are rapid tests less accurate than PCR tests?
Do masks help stop the spread of COVID?
questions.answer: Yes! [Masks](/glossary#face-mask) that cover your nose and mouth are extremely helpful in reducing the spread of COVID. They help to protect you and those around you, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2020/p0714-americans-to-wear-masks.html) and [WHO](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public/when-and-how-to-use-masks). The virus can spread between people interacting in close proximity, even if no one is exhibiting any [symptoms](/glossary#asymptomatic), and wearing a mask gives you an added layer of protection. If there were a medication that dramatically reduced your chances of giving or getting COVID, would you take that medication? In practical terms, a mask is such a medication.

questions.question: What kind of masks are the most effective?
questions.answer: Wearing a [mask](/glossary#face-mask) is extremely important to help contain COVID and decreases the risks for both you and those around you. However, not all masks are created equal. [Experts](https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/11/health/cdc-face-mask-guidelines-wellness/index.html) recommend wearing two- or three-ply masks made with a tight weave of 100 percent cotton. Disposable and silk masks are also effective at repelling droplets. More people are wearing two layers of face masks, which some experts say makes common sense. Most important, however, is making sure your mask fits snugly over the bridge of your nose and below your chin. Studies have shown that loose-fitting masks, such as bandanas and gaiters, are the least effective. While N95 masks are the most effective at filtering out particles, they are still considered critical supplies and should be reserved for health care workers and first responders.

questions.question: How do I discuss the pandemic with friends or family members who aren’t taking it seriously?
questions.answer:
It can be challenging to discuss the pandemic with people who think it’s overblown and aren’t taking precautions. You may be tempted to immediately begin reciting the facts and what the data is showing, but sometimes this can put people off. Instead, it’s important to consider how you are presenting those facts. [Research](https://www.mikeyeomans.info/papers/receptiveness.pdf) finds that conversations are more productive when you avoid condescending tones and let the other person know that you are listening. Try these approaches:

* Actively solicit their perspective on the issue, and show that you are listening (e.g., say “I hear you” or “I see what you mean”). When you understand the beliefs of your friends or family members, you can tailor how you communicate with them in a way that resonates with them instead of turning them off. 
* Avoid allowing your emotions to get the best of you. Stay calm and objective, using a friendly tone to share your thoughts. A collected and approachable tone improves the chances of your counterpart listening to the facts and learning from you.

questions.question: What can I do to help end the pandemic and protect myself from COVID?
questions.answer:
Covid Act Now is a small, independent 501(c)(3) nonprofit founded by volunteers to provide the most timely and accurate local COVID data so that every American can make informed decisions during the pandemic. If you'd like to join this effort, please consider supporting our organization with a tax-deductible [donation](https://www.covidactnow.org/donate).

Your actions matter. You can help protect others and slow the spread of the virus by doing a few simple things:

* Wear a [mask](/glossary#face-mask) unless there is a medical reason not to do so.
* Practice physical distancing to limit person-to-person [transmission](/glossary#transmission).
* Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer frequently.
* Follow limits on gatherings, especially ones that take place indoors.
* Stay home if you are feeling unwell.
* If infected or exposed, strictly follow the rules on isolation and [quarantine](/glossary#quarantine).
* As soon as you are eligible to do so, get vaccinated.
